summary: Calvin W. Hicks was a CIA employee whose career progression, performance, and eventual disability retirement are documented in the files. He was an Operations Officer. The CIA established official cover for him, utilizing the U.S. Army Staff Group, and he was placed on the Domestic Cover List to provide him with an organizational affiliation other than the CIA. He was considered for an overseas assignment in La Paz, Bolivia, in 1966, and a request for an overseas evaluation was submitted. Alias documentation was approved for him for an operational assignment in Florida.
significance: The provided documents do not explicitly link Calvin W. Hicks to the JFK assassination. His significance lies in his role as a CIA Operations Officer, the establishment of cover identities for him, and his potential overseas assignments. The documents highlight the operational activities and personnel management practices of the CIA during the 1960s and 1970s.
